dataIdInfo.idPurp:
Data provided to PPR from PHS in 2022. For more info contact the TreePhilly Team.
Displays areas of the city (city blocks) with the highest to lowest need for additional tree canopy Analysis was done 2020-2021.
dataIdInfo.idAbs:
This layers were created using the datasets listed below and a similar methodology with some variation given that the Canopy Priority Areas layer respresents city blocks. The datasets were chosen after extensive research and vetting with experts, partners and community members. To produce the final layers, the datasets were combined and given more weight or less weight depending upon how important they are to the goal of prioritizing areas based on equity, health and environmental conditions. Read more about each individual dataset used in the analysis below.

-Tree Canopy

Source: University of Vermont Spatial Analysis Laboratory for the Philadelphia 2018 Tree Canopy Assessment

This dataset was developed as part of an Urban Tree Canopy (UTC) assessment for Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. It shows how tree canopy changed during the period 2008-2018, highlighting trees that were gained or lost during the 10-year period. It is intended for use in monitoring patterns of change in Philadelphia tree canopy.

-Heat Exposure

Source: The Philadelphia Department of Public Health

The Heat Exposure layer is part of the Heat Vulnerability Index (HVI). The HVI summarizes the key factors associated with the negative health effects of extreme heat events. The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) characterizes extreme heat events as periods of summertime weather that are substantially hotter and/or more humid than typical for a given location at that time of year.

-Health

Source: Center for Disease Control (CDC)

Tree canopy has proven to directly contribute to community health. The following health indicators from the 500 Cities: Local Data for Better Health 2017 release were chosen based on studies that determined their correlation with tree canopy coverage.

Asthma Rates

Cancer Rates

Poor Mental Health Rates

-Air Quality

Source: Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)

Increased tree canopy can reduce the levels of harmful air pollutants such as nitrogen dioxide, particulate matter, and sulfur dioxide. The EPA’s fine atmospheric particulate matter (pm2.5) monitoring sites collect daily particulate matter concentration levels, which were used to generate Philadelphia’s pm2.5 surface in 2019. Higher pm2.5 concentrations indicate poorer air quality and a greater need for additional tree plantings.

-Traffic Volume

Source: Delaware Valley Regional Planning Commission (DVRPC)

In addition to trees having the power to reduce particulate matter (PM) caused by traffic, studies show that an increase in trees can have an affect on slowing traffic and improving safety for pedestrians, road users, and wildlife.

-US Census Bureau Socioeconomic

Source: U.S. Census Bureau, 2015-2019

A multigenerational history of redlining, policy changes leading to white flight, park budget and service cuts and barriers to tree planting for renters have led to fewer trees in Black and Brown neighborhoods and in areas where there is higher poverty.

Median Household Income

-Impervious Surface

Source: The Philadelphia Water Department (PWD)

A high percent of pavement can many times indicate higher population density and fewer existing trees and greenspace.

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.
